Situation1: Communicate openly to resolve conflicts or misunderstandings.
Situation2: The passenger’s train leaves soon and the station is across town
Story:
My phone buzzed just as I pulled up to the curb, the meter still running from my last fare. It was my younger brother, his name flashing on the screen. “Can we talk? I think we misunderstood each other earlier,” his message read. We’d argued that morning, and I knew he expected me, as his sister, to listen and help us work things out. I wanted to call him back right away, to show him I cared and that our relationship mattered.

But as I glanced in the rearview mirror, my passenger’s anxious eyes met mine. “Please, can you hurry? My train leaves in twenty minutes,” she pleaded, clutching her ticket. As a taxi driver, I was expected to get her to the station safely and on time. The city traffic was thick, and every second counted.

My heart pounded as I gripped the steering wheel, torn between my brother’s need for understanding and my passenger’s urgent timetable. I could feel the weight of both roles pressing down on me, each demanding my attention, each expecting me to put them first.
